title: Conflict Resolution Strategies
description: Master the 5 conflict resolution techniques: Confronting/Problem-Solving, Collaborating, Compromising, Smoothing/Accommodating, and Forcing/Directing. Learn when to use each approach.
objectives: Identify the 5 conflict resolution techniques and their characteristics
Apply appropriate conflict resolution strategy based on conflict type and context
Distinguish constructive conflict (improves outcomes) from destructive conflict (damages relationships)
Recognize when to use Confronting/Problem-Solving (best for win-win) vs Forcing (appropriate for emergencies only)
Understand that conflict is natural and can be productive when managed constructively

screens.headline: Five conflicts. Five different approaches. Which resolution technique fits each situation?

dialogue.text: Not all conflicts are the same. Some need collaborative problem-solving. Others need quick decisions. Some require compromise. Choosing the WRONG approach can escalate tensions or create resentment. Your job: Match the resolution technique to the conflict type.

screens.learningHook: You'll face 5 different conflicts. For each, identify the conflict type and select the most appropriate resolution technique from: Confronting/Problem-Solving, Collaborating, Compromising, Smoothing/Accommodating, Forcing/Directing.

screens.title: Conflict Resolution Technique Selection
screens.instructions: For each conflict scenario, identify the best resolution technique and explain why it's appropriate.

scenarios.title: Conflict 1: Menu Design Philosophy Clash
scenarios.description: Sofia (Head Chef, 15+ years Michelin experience): 'The menu should showcase culinary artistry—bold flavors, complex techniques, high-end ingredients. That's what makes us stand out.' Nina (Marketing Director): 'Customer surveys say 68% want comfort food with healthy options. Bold flavors tested poorly with our target demographic.' Both are passionate. Both have valid points. Both refuse to budge. The launch is 3 weeks away—compromise needed, but both want their vision to succeed.

quotes.text: I didn't train for 15 years to serve mac and cheese. Our reputation depends on culinary excellence.
I have data showing customers want approachable food. Michelin-level complexity alienates 68% of our target market.

questions.question: Which conflict resolution technique should Alex use?

options.text: Forcing/Directing - Alex makes the final call immediately to move forward
Smoothing/Accommodating - Downplay the disagreement to preserve relationship
Confronting/Problem-Solving - Facilitate session to find solution that honors both culinary excellence AND customer preferences
Compromising - Each gets 50% of what they want (6 comfort dishes, 6 Michelin dishes)

feedback.correct: Excellent! Confronting/Problem-Solving is best for fundamental disagreements requiring win-win solutions. Alex facilitated session: 'Sofia, can we elevate comfort food with culinary techniques? Nina, can approachable dishes still showcase artistry?' Result: Elevated comfort food menu (truffle mac & cheese, deconstructed pot pie, gourmet grilled cheese)—customers LOVE it (satisfaction: 92%), Sofia proud of execution, Nina's data validated. Both win.
feedback.incorrect: This fundamental disagreement needs Confronting/Problem-Solving to find win-win solution. Forcing damages relationships, Smoothing avoids the issue, Compromising may satisfy neither party fully. Integrate both perspectives.

scenarios.title: Conflict 2: Emergency Budget Crisis
scenarios.description: Jordan (Finance Director) discovers supplier price increase: Ingredient costs up 40% this week (global supply chain disruption). Budget now NEGATIVE $15K if current menu continues. Jordan to Alex: 'We need to cut costs NOW. Switch to cheaper ingredients or simplify menu TODAY.' Team pushes back: Sofia: 'Quality will suffer.' Maya: 'We've already promoted this menu.' Carlos: 'Can't we find another solution?' Jordan: 'There's NO TIME. We're hemorrhaging money daily. This is a crisis—I need a decision within the hour.'

quotes.text: We're losing $2K per day. We can discuss options later. Right now, we ACT or we go bankrupt.
If we use cheaper ingredients, quality plummets. Customers will notice.
We already sent press releases about this menu.

questions.question: Which conflict resolution technique should Alex use?

options.text: Confronting/Problem-Solving - Facilitate collaborative session to find creative solution
Forcing/Directing - Alex makes immediate decision: switch to cheaper ingredients to stop financial bleeding
Compromising - Find middle ground between quality and cost
Smoothing/Accommodating - Downplay the crisis to avoid panic

feedback.correct: Correct! Forcing/Directing is appropriate for emergencies requiring immediate action. Alex: 'Jordan, implement cost-cutting plan NOW. Team, I know this hurts, but we have no choice—financial survival comes first. We'll revisit quality improvements when budget stabilizes.' Crisis averted. Later (when time allows), Alex facilitates Confronting/Problem-Solving session to find sustainable solution.
feedback.incorrect: This is an emergency (1-hour deadline, financial crisis). Confronting/Problem-Solving requires time for collaboration. Forcing/Directing is appropriate when immediate action is critical for survival.

scenarios.title: Conflict 3: Kitchen Equipment Preference Disagreement
scenarios.description: Maya (Operations Manager) prefers Brand A ovens (energy-efficient, $12K). Carlos (GM) prefers Brand B ovens (traditional, $10K, what he's used to). Both work equally well. Difference is minor: 15% energy savings vs familiarity. This is LOW-STAKES—either choice is fine. Relationship is important (Maya and Carlos work together daily). No urgency (decision needed in 2 weeks).

quotes.text: Brand A saves 15% on energy costs long-term.
I've used Brand B for 20 years. I know how to maintain it.

questions.question: Which conflict resolution technique should Alex use?

options.text: Forcing/Directing - Alex decides which brand to buy
Confronting/Problem-Solving - Deep analysis of energy savings vs maintenance costs
Smoothing/Accommodating - Defer to Carlos (relationship preservation, low stakes)
Compromising - Buy 2 Brand A and 2 Brand B ovens

feedback.correct: Perfect! Smoothing/Accommodating works for low-stakes disagreements where relationship preservation matters more than the specific outcome. Alex: 'Carlos, you'll be using these daily. Let's go with Brand B.' Maya appreciates the relationship-focused decision. Outcome: Carlos happy, Maya understands prioritization, team harmony maintained.
feedback.incorrect: This is low-stakes (both options viable). Confronting/Problem-Solving is overkill, Forcing is unnecessarily authoritarian. Smoothing/Accommodating preserves the relationship when stakes are low.

scenarios.title: Conflict 4: Timeline Pressure - Stakeholder Expectations vs Team Capacity
scenarios.description: Stakeholders want menu launch in 4 weeks. Team says 6 weeks is realistic (testing, training, marketing). Both sides have valid concerns: Stakeholders: 'Competitor launching in 5 weeks—we need first-mover advantage.' Team: 'Rushing = quality issues, untrained staff, failed launch.' No perfect solution—BOTH need to give ground. This requires TRADE-OFFS.

quotes.text: Competitor launches in 5 weeks. We MUST be first to market.
6 weeks is realistic. 4 weeks = we'll fail quality standards.

questions.question: Which conflict resolution technique should Alex use?

options.text: Forcing/Directing - Choose either 4 weeks or 6 weeks and enforce it
Smoothing/Accommodating - Tell team to 'do their best' without addressing timeline
Compromising - Split the difference: 5-week launch with reduced scope (8 dishes instead of 12)
Confronting/Problem-Solving - Find creative solution where both get 100% of needs

feedback.correct: Excellent! Compromising works when both sides must give ground and perfect solution isn't possible. Alex: '5-week launch with 8 signature dishes (not 12). We hit competitive timing AND maintain quality standards. Remaining 4 dishes launch Week 8.' Stakeholders get market timing, Team gets quality assurance. Both sacrifice, both gain.
feedback.incorrect: This requires trade-offs—no perfect win-win exists. Forcing alienates one side, Smoothing avoids the issue. Compromising finds middle ground where both sides sacrifice and gain.

scenarios.title: Conflict 5: Quality Standards Non-Negotiable
scenarios.description: Health inspector found critical violation: refrigeration temperature 45°F (unsafe, legal limit 40°F). Team wants to continue service: 'We'll monitor it manually.' Sofia: 'It's only 5 degrees—food is still good.' Carlos: 'Shutting down costs $10K/day.' Alex (as PM with safety authority): 'This is non-negotiable. Health code violations can shut us down permanently, risk customer illness, destroy reputation. We close kitchen NOW until fridge is fixed.'

quotes.text: It's only 5 degrees. The food is fine.
Shutting down costs us $10K per day.
This is non-negotiable. We cannot risk customer safety or legal violations.

questions.question: Which conflict resolution technique should Alex use?

options.text: Confronting/Problem-Solving - Collaborate to find creative solution
Compromising - Run at 42.5°F (split the difference)
Forcing/Directing - Close kitchen immediately, no discussion
Smoothing/Accommodating - Monitor situation and hope it resolves

feedback.correct: Correct! Forcing/Directing is appropriate for non-negotiable safety/legal/ethical issues. Alex: 'Kitchen is closed until refrigeration is fixed. This isn't up for discussion—it's a legal and safety requirement.' Team initially upset, but respects decision when Alex explains consequences (license suspension, customer illness lawsuits, reputation damage). Safety > Short-term revenue.
feedback.incorrect: This is a non-negotiable safety and legal compliance issue. Collaboration, compromise, or smoothing are inappropriate when health and safety are at stake. Forcing/Directing protects customers and business.

content.introduction: PMI identifies 5 conflict resolution techniques. Each has appropriate use cases and risks.

techniques.name: Confronting / Problem-Solving
techniques.description: Directly address disagreement, find WIN-WIN solution that satisfies both parties
techniques.approach: Collaborative, integrative, 'Let's find a solution where both of us win'
techniques.whenToUse: Fundamental disagreements, important relationships, time available for discussion
techniques.benefits: Both parties satisfied, relationship strengthened, sustainable solution
techniques.risks: Time-consuming, requires goodwill from both sides, may not work in emergencies
techniques.example: Sofia + Nina menu clash → Elevated comfort food (honors culinary artistry AND customer preferences)
techniques.pmbokTerm: Also called Collaborating in some PMI materials

techniques.name: Collaborating
techniques.description: Work together to find mutually beneficial outcome (similar to Confronting/Problem-Solving)
techniques.approach: Joint problem-solving, both parties contribute ideas
techniques.whenToUse: Complex problems requiring multiple perspectives, high-stakes decisions
techniques.benefits: Creative solutions, buy-in from all parties, innovation
techniques.risks: Requires time and trust, may be difficult with power imbalances

techniques.name: Compromising
techniques.description: Both parties give up something to reach middle ground (LOSE-LOSE that's acceptable)
techniques.approach: Split the difference, trade-offs, 'We each sacrifice, we each gain'
techniques.whenToUse: No perfect win-win exists, time constraints, both sides have valid points
techniques.benefits: Quick resolution, perceived fairness, moves forward
techniques.risks: Neither party fully satisfied, may lead to resentment if overused
techniques.example: Timeline conflict → 5-week launch with reduced scope (8 dishes instead of 12)

techniques.name: Smoothing / Accommodating
techniques.description: Emphasize agreement, downplay disagreement, defer to other party
techniques.approach: Relationship preservation over winning, 'Your way is fine'
techniques.whenToUse: Low-stakes disagreements, relationship more important than outcome, maintain harmony
techniques.risks: Issue may resurface, one party's needs unmet, can build resentment if overused
techniques.example: Equipment preference → Defer to Carlos (low stakes, relationship matters)

techniques.name: Forcing / Directing
techniques.description: Push one viewpoint at expense of others (WIN-LOSE)
techniques.whenToUse: Emergencies, safety/legal/ethical issues, when PM has clear authority
techniques.benefits: Fast decision, clear direction, appropriate in crisis
techniques.risks: Damages relationships, kills morale if overused, no buy-in
techniques.example: Budget crisis → Immediate cost-cutting, Health violation → Close kitchen NOW

content.pmbokRef: PMBOK 6th Edition, page 349; PMBOK 7th Edition addresses conflict in Team Performance Domain

decisionFactors.high: Avoid Forcing/Directing, prefer Confronting or Smoothing

insights.title: Conflict is natural and can be productive
insights.explanation: Constructive conflict (different perspectives, healthy debate) IMPROVES decisions. Destructive conflict (personal attacks, blame) damages relationships.
insights.action: Encourage constructive conflict, address destructive conflict immediately

insights.title: Confronting/Problem-Solving is preferred (when time allows)
insights.explanation: PMI recommends Confronting as the BEST technique because it creates win-win solutions and strengthens relationships.
insights.caution: But NOT always appropriate—emergencies require Forcing, low-stakes require Smoothing

insights.title: Forcing/Directing damages relationships if overused
insights.explanation: Appropriate for emergencies and non-negotiables, but kills morale and buy-in if used routinely.
insights.guideline: Use sparingly, explain rationale when used

insights.title: Smoothing doesn't resolve underlying issues
insights.explanation: Downplaying disagreements preserves short-term harmony but issues may resurface.

insights.title: Context determines technique effectiveness
insights.explanation: No single technique works for all conflicts. Match technique to situation.
insights.example: Confronting for menu design, Forcing for health violation, Smoothing for equipment preference

menu_correct.text: I was ready to fight for Michelin-level complexity. You facilitated a session where Nina and I BOTH won—elevated comfort food showcases artistry AND satisfies customers. 92% satisfaction proves it worked.

budget_correct.text: You made the hard call immediately when financial crisis hit. We stopped the bleeding. Later, you facilitated sustainable solution. That's good leadership.

equipment_correct.text: You let me choose Brand B even though Maya had valid energy savings argument. I appreciate you prioritizing my daily comfort over minor cost difference. Relationship matters.

timeline_correct.text: I found middle ground: 5-week launch with 8 dishes. Stakeholders got competitive timing, team got quality assurance. Neither got 100%, both got what matters most.

quality_correct.text: I closed the kitchen immediately despite $10K/day cost. Health code violations are non-negotiable. Team initially upset, but respected the decision when I explained legal and safety consequences.

screens.title: New Conflict: Remote Team Disagreement
screens.context: SF team (in-office) vs Mexico team (remote) conflict over work hours. SF wants daily 9am PT sync calls. Mexico: 'That's 11am our time—disrupts our morning prep.' Both sides frustrated. Relationship deteriorating. No safety/legal issue. Time available to discuss. Win-win likely possible.

questions.question: Which technique should Alex use for this conflict?

options.text: Forcing/Directing - Mandate 9am PT calls (SF is HQ)
Smoothing/Accommodating - Cancel sync calls to avoid conflict
Confronting/Problem-Solving - Facilitate session to find timing that works for both teams
Compromising - Rotate call times weekly (SF suffers one week, Mexico suffers next)

feedback.correct: Excellent! This is perfect for Confronting/Problem-Solving: High stakes (relationship deteriorating), time available, win-win possible. Alex facilitates: 'What if we do async daily updates (Slack) + bi-weekly 30-min sync at 12pm PT / 2pm Mexico (both during lunch)?' Both teams win: Less meeting disruption + meaningful sync time.
feedback.incorrect: This situation has time for discussion and win-win is possible. Forcing damages relationships, Smoothing avoids the issue, Compromising makes both suffer. Confronting finds creative solution.

screens.title: Mastering Conflict Resolution
screens.summary: You've learned the 5 conflict resolution techniques and when to apply each. Confronting/Problem-Solving is preferred for win-win solutions, but emergencies require Forcing, low-stakes require Smoothing, and trade-offs require Compromising.
takeaways: Confronting/Problem-Solving: Best for win-win solutions, requires time and goodwill
Collaborating: Joint problem-solving, similar to Confronting
Compromising: Both parties give ground, use when perfect solution doesn't exist
Smoothing/Accommodating: Preserve relationships, use for low-stakes disagreements
Forcing/Directing: Emergency or non-negotiable issues ONLY (safety, legal, ethical)
Conflict is natural and productive when managed constructively
Context determines technique effectiveness—no one-size-fits-all approach

artifacts.description: Framework for choosing appropriate technique based on context

artifacts.description: When to use, benefits, and risks of each technique

characterClosing.text: You matched techniques to context perfectly. Menu design needed Confronting (win-win), budget crisis needed Forcing (emergency), equipment needed Smoothing (low stakes), timeline needed Compromising (trade-offs), health violation needed Forcing (non-negotiable). That's mastery.
